docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Tell the Truth: Does This Index Make Me Look Fat?'' (Week in Review, Nov. 28) shows how inane and outdated the body mass index is. The index was developed decades ago by life insurance companies, based on mortality data at the time. Advances in research and technology have undoubtedly rendered it of little scientific value. Still, the index is so ingrained in our society that it does not stop many people from obsessively trying to achieve an ideal weight, nor does it halt athletic coaches from riding athletes to achieve a desirable weight-height ratio.

headline.main: By This Measure, They're Fat. Are You?

docs.abstract: Lee H Igel letter contends body mass index is outdated and useless (Nov 28 article); drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that it would spend $300 million in cash to buy Definity Health, a smaller health technology company specializing in health plans that allow consumers leeway in directing their medical spending. The price -- not a big number for UnitedHealth -- was the latest move in the company's strategy of diversification from its signature managed care business.
docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group will spend $300 million in cash to buy Definity Health, smaller health technology company specializing in health plans that allow consumers leeway in directing their medical spending; acquisition is latest move in company's strategy of diversification from its signature managed care business; will add 500,000 customers (Market Place column) (M)
docs.snippet: The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest health insurance company, said that it would buy Definity Health, a smaller health technology company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine a 20-year-old woman who refuses to eat anything except carrots and toast because she is afraid of gaining weight, even though she is 5-foot-8 and weighs only 99 pounds. She exercises to the point of exhaustion five mornings a week because, though she is bone-thin, she thinks her thighs are too flabby. Her periods are irregular, but she has never gone more than three months without menstruating. Another woman, who is also 20 and also 5-foot-8, has an opposite eating pattern. She goes without eating all day, and starting at 6 p.m. she eats nonstop, whatever she can get her hands on. Her favorite pastime is to sit in front of the television with a gallon of mocha-chip ice cream. She maintains a normal weight of 130 by occasionally forcing herself to vomit. But purging is not always easy in her college dormitory, with four young women sharing a single bathroom, so she ends up vomiting, on average, about once a week.

headline.main: Sorry. Your Eating Disorder Doesn't Meet Our Criteria.

docs.abstract: American Psychiatric Assn, which is currently revising its Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, is exploring ways to define eating disorders that do not strictly fall into two main categories of anorexia nervosa and bulimia; other disorders are now lumped into catch-all category known as Ednos, eating disorder not otherwise specified; various non-specific eating disorders described; Dr Michael First, Columbia University clinical psychology associate professor and member of assn planning group for manual, explains three criteria to be met before disorder is specifically named; often disorders without labels are not covered by health insurance and are not adequately researched; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For years, doctors have been relying on a vague nondiagnosis known by the acronym Ednos: eating disorder not otherwise specified.

docs.lead_paragraph: If there was one thing Cathy and Robert Jacob agreed on, their lawyers said recently, it was that their marriage was over. After 26 years, they divorced in January 2003, but Mr. Jacob was unhappy with the financial terms imposed by the court and appealed. Last June, an appellate court reviewed the decision and decided that neither of the Jacobs had shown proper grounds for divorce, an unexpected decision that would be unlikely in other states.

headline.main: A New Push to Loosen New York's Divorce Law

docs.abstract: Push is on for New York State to change its tough divorce law; matrimonial lawyers, bar associations and judges say law is archaic and heightens hostilities between spouses, which particularly hurts children; New York is one of handful of states that does not allow one spouse to unilaterally end marriage, and also one of few without some form of one-step, no-fault divorce; New York State Bar Assn and city bar back legislative change in Albany to add no-fault grounds, and several powerful legislators appear to be receptive; Women's Bar Assn of State of NY has reversed its longtime opposition to no-fault; theories about why state has been so conservative on matters of family law include Catholic Church's objections to easier divorces, concern of women's groups about economic harm to women from inequitable financial settlements, divorce reformers' focus on other issues and generally sclerotic Legislature; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Lawyers and judges are pushing to have New York's divorce law changed, saying it is archaic and heightens hostilities between spouses.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Since the election, hardly a day seems to go by without someone in the Bush administration claiming that the mandate it received indisputably vindicates one of its policies (''The Real Environmental Mandate,'' editorial, Nov. 26).
docs.abstract: Russ Weiss letter contends 51 percent of vote that gave Pres Bush victory does not constitute mandate that vindicates its environmental policies (Nov 26 editorial)
